ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: good in-depth look at different energy technologies. whether you know nothing or a lot about energy you can get a lot out of the class.
Yes. Great class. Hopefully the reading can be cut down and it can be made more discussion based.
I'd highly recommend the seminar to anyone who's interested in energy economics.
Yes, if you are looking for a crash course on all issues of all energy sources.

Professor Kessides is a knowledgeable and kind professor. The coursework has a fair workload, with one policy paper and research paper, and Professor Kessides makes an incredible effort to make himself available to help you work through any concerns you may have. The class tends to be taught more as a lecture than as a discussion. I recommend this course!

It was a great class with a very knowledgeable economist from the world bank. He is not a professor by profession so he was new, which made the course inevitably confusing at times with the pace and assignment. But being interested in the topic of energy, I still got a lot from the class and thought it was interesting.
Really good class, not tons of work (two big papers.) Professor is good.
Yes, as it gives a great intro into a topic and is taught by someone with a more practical policy perspective than other energy econ or engineering classes
It is an excellent survey course of energy issues and great if you want a broad idea of the energy sector. Take it!!
Good overview of energy topics for someone who is interested in the topic and looking for an introductory course
